subsc: Petrochemicals and fertilizers,Central government administration,Agricultural extension and research
trustfund:
TF024950-INDIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF034986-ETHIOPIA - NATIONAL FERTILIZER PROJECT,TF023974-ITALIAN GRANT FOR THE NATIONAL
            FERTILIZER SECTOR PROJECT,TF020718-NATIONAL FERTILIZER SECTOR PROJECT,TF020011-NATIONAL FERTILIZER SECTOR
            PROJECT II,TF020013-ETHIOPIA NATIONAL FERTILIZER
            SECTOR PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the National Fertilizer
            Sector Project for Ethipia was unsatisfactory, the
            sustainability was unlikely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were unsatisfactory. Involvement of agricultural extension
            agents in distribution and credit administration impeded
            development of the private sector and undermined the longer
            term function of extension. Financing fertilizer imports
            through separately mechanisms of foreign exchange allocation
            introduces inefficiencies in the fertilizer industry. There
            is a need to move away from project based fertilizers
            imports in favor of general foreign exchange management. In
            a country that is highly susceptible to drought like
            Ethiopia, use of fertilizer can accentuate the hardship
            caused by insufficient precipitation, putting in peril large
            numbers of farmers and the financial institutions that serve
            them. It is important to adopt a holistic approach to input
            market development and seek coverage in seeds availability
            and fertilizers as one without the other cannot give optimal
            returns. The grain market crash of 2001, and the resulting
            hardship in credit repayments and the precipitous drop in
            fertilizer consumption in 2002, clearly illustrate the
            importance of focusing as much on agricultural input markets
            as on output markets.
